content.title: Sclerotherapy
content.definition: Minimally invasive procedure involving injection of a sclerosing agent into abnormal veins to cause endothelial damage, fibrosis, and eventual obliteration of the treated vessel. Primary treatment for spider veins and reticular veins; adjunct to other treatments for varicose veins.

key_concepts.description: Sclerosant damages endothelium → inflammatory response → fibrosis → vessel occlusion and resorption. Direct contact time and concentration determine efficacy
Sodium tetradecyl sulfate (STS/Sotradecol), polidocanol (Asclera) - most commonly used; work by disrupting cell membranes; can be foamed for enhanced effect
Hypertonic saline (23.4%), hypertonic glucose - damage cells by dehydration; painful on injection; less commonly used now
Mixing liquid sclerosant with air creates microfoam (Tessari method); displaces blood for better wall contact; enhanced efficacy for larger veins; allows ultrasound visualization
Spider veins (telangiectasias C1), reticular veins, small varicose veins; residual varicose veins after ablation or surgery; malformations; cosmetic improvement
Allergy to sclerosant; acute DVT; severe PAD (relative); immobility; known right-to-left shunt (risk of stroke with foam); pregnancy/lactation
Inject small volumes (0.1-0.5 mL per site); multiple punctures along vein; immediate compression; ultrasound guidance for larger veins (UGFS - ultrasound-guided foam sclerotherapy)
Compression stockings for 1-3 weeks; walking encouraged; avoid prolonged standing, hot baths, sun exposure; multiple sessions often needed
Common: bruising, hyperpigmentation (up to 30%), matting (new telangiectasias), pain. Rare: skin necrosis, DVT, visual disturbance (foam), allergic reaction
Hemosiderin deposition from extravasated RBCs; more common with hypertonic saline; usually resolves within 12 months; minimize by proper concentration and compression
With foam sclerotherapy: transient visual disturbance, migraine-like symptoms due to paradoxical embolism through PFO; rare but important to counsel patients

explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Sclerotherapy.

learning_objectives: Understand mechanism and types of sclerosants
Understand foam sclerotherapy advantages and risks
clinical_pearls: STS and polidocanol are the workhorses - detergent sclerosants
Foam displaces blood = better wall contact = better efficacy
Hyperpigmentation is common (30%) but usually temporary
Matting (new spider veins) may appear - warn patients
PFO + foam = risk of paradoxical embolism - ask about cardiac history
Compression after treatment is essential for success
common_mistakes: Using too high concentration (increases necrosis risk)
Injecting too large volume at single site
Using foam in patient with known PFO
Expecting single session to be curative
